content:
• Monday, December 7, 2015
  • FELP

    Foresight Energy likely to suspend distribution, -15% AH

    • Foresight Energy (NYSE:FELP) -15.5% AH after saying it likely will suspend distributions on its common units by the end of the year.
    • A Friday decision by the Delaware Court of Chancery found that Murray Energy’s purchase of a big stake in FELP triggered a debt repurchase provision, which could force FELP to pay 101% of the premium on $600M in bonds it issued two years ago.
    • "If discussions with the bondholders are unsuccessful, it could result in an adverse judgment being rendered," FELP says. "We would seek to get such order stayed while the order is appealed to the Delaware Supreme Court, but such a stay could require posting of a bond."
     
     
     
     
    | 6:49 PM | 2 Comments
  • CMCSA

    Could Comcast make a Sprint/T-Mobile marriage happen?

    • A serious courtship between America's No. 3 and No. 4 wireless providers went sour in 2014 after the government made it clear it wanted four players, and since then merger speculation (particularly among suffering Sprint shareholders) has held that any new move wuold have to wait for a new administration.
    • But what if the relationship could be rekindled earlier? Overtures toward wireless service from Comcast (CMCSA -0.6%), or other cable firms yet to express interest, could allow for a union between T-Mobile (TMUS +3.2%) and Sprint (S +2.8%) while maintaining the desired competitive players.
    • Comcast started a process that would let it resell Verizon airwaves and acknowledged it was testing a service for a launch sometimes in the future. One catalyst could be a heavy bid into the March spectrum auction.
    • "It seems clear that Sprint is playing for time, presumably to try again to merge with T-Mobile in 2017-18 under a new administration," says analyst Crag Moffett. "By then, Comcast will likely have bought spectrum in the TV broadcast auction, making it plausible to argue that a Sprint/T-Mobile combination can be called a five-to-four merger, not a four-to-three."
    • Several outcomes are yet possible, though, and not all favor Sprint: Comcast could use an auction bid as a precursor for its own T-Mobile buyout; firms like Alphabet or Amazon.com could buy spectrum; or private investor Chamath Palihapitiya could succeed in an audacious plan to bid billions of dollars in the auction to create a new player called Rama.
    • Previously: Comcast: Testing wireless service, but in no hurry to launch (Oct. 27 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 6:47 PM | 19 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: VNCE +7.2%. CLLS +5.4%. WY +3.8%. CENX +3.6%. CENT +2.3%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: OUTR -23.4%. EVA -12.4%. UNFI -9.1%. CMG -4.7%. DPLO -3.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM | 3 Comments
  • FIT

    Fitbit closes higher following Barron's/WSJ columns

    • Fitbit (NYSE:FIT) closed up 2.2% today (though equity markets fell) after Barron's Alexander Eule and the WSJ's Dan Gallagher each issued columns that raised a slew of concerns about the activity tracker leader, but remained cautiously optimistic.
    • Eule, who has previously written bearish columns on GoPro, is worried about a mid-December lockup expiration, competition from the likes of Apple, Microsoft, and Xiaomi, and a valuation of 29x 2016E EPS. However, he adds Fitbit's devices have broader appeal than GoPro's, particularly with insurers and enterprises giving their support, and declares the company to have "won the marketing battle" for now.
    • Gallagher raises some of the same concerns, and notes Xiaomi's Mi Band tracker sells for less than $20. But he adds fears that Apple Watch would decimate Fitbit haven't panned out, Fitbit's ASP ($85.75 in Q3, up 31% Y/Y) continues rising, and that Xiaomi's sales are mostly limited to China. "Fitbit’s proven ability to outrun its rivals should keep it in the race—and perhaps even worth a holiday splurge."
    • Last week: Morgan Stanley reports positive Fitbit holiday checks
     
     
     
     
    | 5:34 PM
  • GRUB

    GrubHub acquires Western-focused Delivered Dish service

    • GrubHub (GRUB -1.7%) has acquired Delivered Dish, a delivery service operating with hundreds of restaurants in seven markets.
    • Delivered Dish, based in Portland, Ore., offers service in areas including Denver, Las Vegas, San Diego, El Paso and Albuquerque as well as its Portland base.
    • GrubHub currently serves 30 markets and expects to be in more than 40 by the end of the year.
    • Shares were down 0.8% after hours prior to the news.
    • Previously: Mizuho starts GrubHub at Buy with $31 target (Dec. 02 2015)
    • Previously: GrubHub expands delivery into Atlanta (Nov. 19 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:22 PM
  • OUTR

    Outerwall down 24.2% after resuming trading following warning

    • After coming off a halt, Outerwall (NASDAQ:OUTR) has plunged to $44.03 after hours after cutting its full-year guidance and announcing Redbox division chief Mark Horak is leaving.
    • Shares are at their lowest levels since Nov. 2012. With Redbox-related fears running high, Outerwall now trades for just 5.6x the midpoint of its revised 2015 core EPS guidance range.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:22 PM
  • GPRO

    GoPro slumps again after Dougherty reports of weak Google trends; JPMorgan defends

    • GoPro (NASDAQ:GPRO) fell 2.7% today amid a 0.8% Nasdaq drop after Dougherty's Charles Anderson (Buy rating, $30 target) reported Google searches for the GoPro brand were down 17% Y/Y globally and 10% in the U.S. last week, after dropping 25% and 10% the prior week. YouTube searches for GoPro were down 26% Y/Y and 28% in the prior week.
    • Likewise, the position of GoPro's app on iPhone, Google Play, and iPad download charts was respectively down 29%, 39%, and 27% Y/Y. Year-ago search and download activity benefited from the Hero4 camera line launch.
    • On the bright side, Anderson notes GoPro's app is outperforming Xiaomi's camera app in the Chinese Google Play store. He also observes app downloads don't necessarily reflect sales of the $130 Hero camera (doesn't have Wi-Fi) or repeat GoPro buyers.
    • JPMorgan's Paul Coster (Overweight rating, target cut by $10 to $45) defended GoPro: Though (like others) he sees major Q4 camera discounting, Coster forecasts 15% 2016 sales growth (weighted towards 2H16), aided by expected Black and Silver camera refreshes and a quad-copter drone launch.
    • Coster: "We think innovation features [for new cameras] could include higher resolution, frame rates, improved stabilization, user-friendly editing capabilities, HDR capabilities ... A GoPro drone is slated for early 2016, and we expect GoPro to take immediate share from market leader DJI, based on brand, ecosystem, and channel distribution."
    • Last week: GoPro cuts Hero4 Session's price to $199, GoPro lower following Ambarella's guidance
     
     
     
     
    | 4:54 PM | 12 Comments
  • OUTR

    Outerwall cuts guidance on Redbox results; unit chief leaving

    • Outerwall (OUTR -2%) has cut guidance in a new update based on lower-than-expected revenue from its Redbox unit, and said the leader of that unit is leaving the company.
    • Mark Horak is exiting his post, and Outerwall CEO Erik Prusch will be interim president of the unit until a replacement is named.
    • For the full year, the company now sees Redbox revenues coming in at $1.75B-$1.765B, down from a previous $1.79B-$1.815B. Consolidate revenue is expected in the range of $2.165B-$2.19B, down from a previous $2.205B-$2.24B (and below consensus of $2.223B).
    • The company's lowered expected core EPS from continuing operations of $7.65-$8.15, down from $8.82-$9.52, and free cash flow of $235M-$255M, down from $252M-$282M.
    • The company is also discontinuing its SampleIt concept, and taking a noncash charge of about $4.5M in Q4 (about $0.16 impact on core diluted EPS from continuing operations).
    • Shares are up 0.2% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:33 PM | 1 Comment
  • VNR

    Vanguard Natural Resources, Legacy Reserves downgraded at Stifel

    • Vanguard Natural Resources (VNR -27.9%) is walloped after Stifel downgrades shares to Sell from Hold with a $3 price target, cut from $4, citing VNR's elevated credit facility utilization (94%) and leverage approaching debt covenants in FY 2016; however, the firm continues to view the partnership managing through the current commodity environment.
    • Stifel downgrades Legacy Reserves (LGCY -19.8%) to Hold from Buy, given LGCY's elevated balance sheet risks under the "lower for longer" commodity environment, even as it continues to view the partnership as one of the best operators with a strong track record of reducing costs (Briefing.com).
     
     
     
     
    | 3:57 PM | 46 Comments
  • NWL

    Merger talk between Jarden and Newell Rubbermaid reported

    • Newell Rubbermaid (NWL +8.8%) and Jarden (JAH +7.3%) are conducting talks over a merger, sources tell The Wall Street Journal.
    • The two consumer products companies overlap in a number of categories.
    • Specific terms over a combination aren't yet known.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:55 PM | 2 Comments
  • SLG

    SL Green guides for about 9% FFO growth in 2016

    • As part of the company's investor day presentation, management guides to 2016 FFO per share of $6.90-$7, and confirms previous full-year 2015 FFO guidance of $6.34-$6.37.
    • Webcast
    • Previously: SL Green halted with news pending (Dec. 7)
    • SLG -1.6% on the session, but higher since the release of the guidance.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:53 PM
  • TCPTF

    Thompson Creek downgraded, Stillwater Mining target slashed at RBC

    • Thompson Creek Metals (TC -7.4%) is downgraded to Underperform from Sector Perform with a $0.30 price target, cut from $0.80, at RBC Capital, which says the lower copper price environment the firm now forecasts will make it more difficult for TC to satisfy its creditors as its debt begins to mature in 2017 and at the same time realize value for its shareholders.
    • The firm also lowers its price target for Stillwater Mining (SWC -9.1%) to $11 from $15, citing lower near-term prices for platinum group metals and long-term palladium prices to $800/oz. from $900/oz. (Briefing.com)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:43 PM | 4 Comments
  • SLCA

    Frac sand companies win Buy ratings at DA Davidson

    • Frac sand providers U.S. Silica (SLCA -5.5%), Emerge Energy Services (EMES -9.1%), Hi-Crush Partners (HCLP -1.9%) and Fairmount Santrol (FMSA -9%) are initiated with Buy ratings at DA Davidson (I, II, III, IV), which believes overall sand demand will remain relatively resilient despite the decrease in commodity prices and subsequent reduction in oilfield activity.
    • The firm also believe frac sand MLPs have been disproportionately hard hit over distribution cuts and are currently trading at a compelling discount to corporate peers.
    • Davidson issues respective stock price targets of $32, $10, $11 and $4 for SLCA, EMES, HCLP and FMSA.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:29 PM | 24 Comments
  • KBR

    KBR cut to Sell at Goldman as large scale energy projects are reduced

    • KBR (KBR -5.1%) is downgraded to Sell from Neutral with a $19 price target at Goldman Sachs, citing concerns about the impact of "significant cuts to large scale energy projects - particularly for LNG - and slowing nitrogen capex, a key KBR market," on the company’s earnings growth in the medium term.
    • Goldman says it is positive on KBR’s turnaround progress, but believes further margin expansion will prove challenging amid an extended commodity deflation cycle.
    • While KBR’s Magnolia project appears to be on track, the prospects to replace completed KBR projects in Australia are limited, the firm says.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:14 PM | 2 Comments
  • ORAN

    Orange up 1.3% on report of talks to buy Bouyges media/telecom assets

    • Orange (NYSE:ORAN) moved from the flat line to up 1.4% on a Bloomberg report that it's in early talks to acquire the telecom/media assets of Bouygues SA (OTCPK:BOUYY).
    • That could be one of a number of directions for Orange. A possible deal would see Bouygues extracting the construction unit and retaining a minority stake, sources said.
    • Bouygues had fended off a bid for its phone assets this summer by Patrick Drahi's Numericable-SFR (OTCPK:NUMCF). The phone unit was a cash cow before having to fight a price war with hard-charging Iliad (OTCPK:ILIAY), pressing it for third place in the mobile market.
    • Most of Bouygues' media business is tied up in a minority stake in Societe Television Francaise 1, the leading private TV group in France.
    • Previously: Bouygues Telecom rejects Altice's €10B buyout bid (Jun. 23 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:10 PM
  • EQT

    EQT sees 2016 700B-720B cfe production sales volume, $1B in capex

    • EQT Corp. (EQT -4.2%) outlines plans to spend ~$1B in 2016, including EQT Midstream Partners (EQM -4%), more than 80% of which will go towards well development in the Marcellus and the Utica shales.
    • EQT sees production sales volume in 2016 of 700B-720B cfe, with plans to drill 72 Marcellus wells with an average lateral length of 7K ft., all of which will be on multi-well pads to maximize operational efficiency and well economics; EQT also plans to drill five deep Utica wells with an average lateral length of 5.2K ft., with possibly up to another five wells drilled.
    • EQT says the Huron gathering system will not be dropped into EQM, because of declining volume and cash flow trajectory.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:59 PM | 2 Comments
  • PBR

    Petrobras' hedge accounting poses dividend risks, Deutsche Bank says

    • Petrobras' (PBR -5.9%) hedge accounting poses dividend risks, and its $21B in foreign exchange loses could be a "time bomb," Deutsche Bank analyst Alexander Burgansky says in maintaining his Sell rating on the stock.
    • With unrecognized after-tax forex losses of $21B, hedge accounting will have a material impact on PBR’s future reported earnings, dividends and equity valuation, Burgansky says, adding that PBR likely will partially discontinue hedge accounting in 2015, which would increase the likelihood of an accounting loss in 2015 and thus reduce the likelihood of a preferred dividend being declared.
    • If PBR continues using hedge accounting, it would need to start reclassifying the gigantic $21B unrealized after-tax forex loss into its income statement starting from 2016, significantly depressing its accounting earnings for the next nine years (until 2025), the analyst says; "if so, the company’s earnings will be depressed for years to come, delaying the first ordinary dividend until 2018."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:47 PM | 5 Comments
  • SPLS

    Staples and Office Depot slump after FTC files merger-busting lawsuit

    • The FTC announces it filed a lawsuit to block the Staples (SPLS -11.5%) and Office Depot (ODP -15.3%) merger.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:39 PM | 10 Comments
  • NTR

    Potash slides as analyst questions safety of dividend

    • Potash Corp. (POT -2.7%) is lower after BofA analyst Steve Byrne reinstated coverage of the stock with an Underperform rating and $20 price target, expecting increased capex in the potash industry over the last decade to depress operating rates in the next couple of years.
    • Increased capacity due to the incentivization of brownfield expansion and the current favorable production price of potash coupled with the weakening outlook in farm income levels may all influence potash price discipline, Byrne believes.
    • If potash prices fall towards the marginal cost of $200/metric ton, Byrne thinks market forces could push prices even lower to encourage global capacity reduction; in such an environment, POT would be able to maintain its dividend only if it meaningfully cut capex or increased production rates.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:37 PM | 14 Comments
  • SRE

    Sempra Energy denies reports about costs of California gas leak

    • Sempra Energy (SRE -2.4%) says any estimates published in the media discussing the potential costs of a leaking well at its Southern California Gas subsidiary's Aliso Canyon natural gas storage facility are "premature and purely speculative."
    • SRE says it will assess the amount of gas lost from the leak, which was discovered in late October, and report it to regulators, but believes it is not yet possible to accurately measure the amount of gas being lost from the leak.
    • Bloomberg calculates that SRE faces as much as $900M in costs including relocation and legal expenses, not including potential fines and penalties, and believes the 8,700-ft. deep well has leaked 800K metric tons of gases, or ~25% of California emissions.
    • Dennis Arriola, president and CEO of Southern California Gas, says it will take at least three months to stop the leak; on Friday, the company began drilling a relief well that will be used to plug the leak.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:19 PM | 1 Comment
  • BNTC

    Benitec Biopharma's ddRNAi therapeutic candidate shows potent anti-HBV antigen activity in preclinical testing; shares up 14%

    • Ultra thinly traded nano cap Benitec Biopharma (BNTC +13.6%) heads north on a 40% surge in volume, albeit on very modest turnover of less than 20K shares, in response to its announcement that its DNA-directed RNA interference (ddRNAi)-based therapy candidate, BB-HB-331, reduced 90% of the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and e-antigen (HbeAg) in infected liver cells compared to untreated controls in preclinical testing. In addition, core antigen decreased by ~1 log (10-fold) and intracellular HBV DNA decreased 85% after only 23 days.
    • The design and construction of BB-HB-331 mimics the company's lead product candidate, TT-034. The company intends to proceed to in vivo studies as soon as feasible.
    • TT-034, currently undergoing testing in the U.S. for the potential treatment of HCV, is a ddRNAi-based multi-cassette vector that targets three separate regions of HCV simultaneously, thus preventing the generation of drug-resistant mutations. It also stimulates liver cells to continue to produce molecules that turn off the replication of HCV for as long as the liver cells persist thereby protecting against re-infection, all from a single dose.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:37 PM

  • Treasurys rally as stocks and oil sink

    • Touching as high as 2.30% earlier in the session, the 10-year Treasury yield has tumbled all the way to 2.21%. The move comes with the major averages lower by more than 1%, led by the energy sector's near-5% decline as oil plunges below $38 per barrel.
    • The flow into the safety of government paper is in contrast with the continued exit from high-yield.
    • Next week's Fed rate hike in the face of plunging commodity prices (it's not just oil headed south) and signs of strain in credit markets should make for interesting reactions.
    • TLT +1.3%, TBT -2.6%
    • ETFs: TBT, TLT, TMV, TBF, EDV, TMF, TTT, ZROZ, TLH, SBND, VGLT, UBT, DLBS, TLO, TENZ, LBND, DLBL, TYBS, VUSTX
     
     
     
     
    | 1:11 PM | 6 Comments
  • XBIT

    XBiotech's lead product candidate successful in late-stage study in colorectal cancer; shares up 69%

    • Thinly traded micro cap XBiotech (XBIT +69.2%) jumps on an impressive 25x surge in volume in response to its announcement that a European Phase 3 trial evaluating lead product candidate Xilonix in advanced colorectal cancer met its primary endpoint. The positive news is a reversal of fortune considering the news several weeks ago about problems with the management of the trial.
    • 33% (n=68) of the 207 patients randomized to receive Xilonix met responder criteria compared 19% (n=19) of the 102 placebo recipients (p=0.009).
    • The study assessed Xilonix's anti-tumor activity using a novel co-primary endpoint based on responder analysis as a surrogate measure. X-ray imaging was used to quantify the change in lean body mass while a questionnaire called the European Organization of Research and Evaluation of Cancer (EORTC-QLQ-C30) was used to assess health status. Responders were those who showed conserved/improved lean body mass and EORT-QLQ-C30 performance over the treatment period (four cycles of therapy over eight weeks). Xilonix is the first anti-cancer agent evaluated under the European Medicines Agency's guidance using the surrogate measure.
    • Xilonix is a True Human monoclonal antibody (IgG1k) that binds to interleukin-1alpha, thereby blocking the inflammation that supports tumor growth, spread and symptomatic effects of the cancer.
    • The company intends to promptly proceed with its regulatory submissions.
    • Previously: XBiotech crumbles 32% over foul-ups in Europe-based Xilonix study (Nov. 24)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:56 PM
  • JSDA

    More beverage sector movers after Keurig takeover deal

    • Jones Soda (OTC:JSDA +7.6%), Reed's (REED +1.9%), and Coca-Cola Bottling Co. (COKE +2.7%) are three more beverage stocks on the move after Keurig Green Mountain is taken private at a lush premium.
    • Previously: Keurig Green Mountain bought by JAB at 78% premium (Dec. 07 2015)
    • Previously: Ripple effects from the Keurig Green Mountain buyout (Dec. 07 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:48 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: XBIT +73%. GMCR +73%. GAI +25%. EFUT +22%. JOB +14%. YECO-OLD +14%. BNTC +14%. MEIP +12%. ARWR +11%. BOTA +10%.
    • Losers: THLD -81%. BLUE -36%. VNR -25%. BBEP -25%. TCCO -22%. MCEP -22%. GBT -21%. OTC:JONE -21%. AGIO -19%. LGCY -18%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:48 PM
  • APC

    FT: Anadarko Petroleum to take Africa decision in 2016

    • Anadarko Petroleum (APC -5.8%) plans to make a final decision in H2 next year on how it will develop the vast gas discoveries it has made offshore Mozambique, CEO Al Walker tells Financial Times.
    • APC has discovered more than 75T cf of gas in the Rovuma Basin, while Eni (E -2.8%) has identified ~85T cf; combined, the resources have the potential to transform Mozambique into one of the world’s top producers of liquefied natural gas.
    • "By the end of the 2020s, as we approach 2030, Mozambique probably will be second only to Qatar in terms of providing lowest-cost LNG in the world," the CEO says.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:47 PM | 1 Comment
  • TCAP-OLD

    Energy woes sink BDCs

    • Triangle Capital (TCAP-OLD -9.7%) is leading the way lower in the sector as oil tumbles all the way down to $38 per barrel, the XLE slides 4.5%, and junk bonds sell off again.
    • OHA Investment (OHAI -6.4%), PennantPark Investment (PNNT -4.6%), Prospect Capital (PSEC -2.8%), Ares Capital (ARCC -2.5%), Apollo Investment (AINV -4.5%), KCAP Financial (KCAP -3.4%), Main Street Capital (MAIN -1.1%).
    • ETFs: BDCL, BDCS, BIZD, FGB
     
     
     
     
    | 12:27 PM | 42 Comments
  • RIG

    Transocean signs new rig contract

    • Transocean (RIG -2.2%) says the harsh environment floater Henry Goodrich was awarded a two-year contract with Husky Oil offshore Canada at a dayrate of $275K, below the rig's prior $347K-$476K dayrate range but above RIG’s Q2 2015 average cost of $147K/day for the harsh environment floater fleet.
    • RIG says its current backlog stands at $16.8B, down slightly from $16.9B as of Oct. 26 as the company continues to burn through backlog faster than its signing new contracts, Evercore analysts say, as they continue to rate RIG as a Sell.
    • RIG shares are lower but far less than most energy companies, which are taking a beating today as crude oil prices slide to multiyear lows.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:19 PM | 1 Comment
  • OMC

    Omnicom +1.8% as it scores coup with closely watched Procter & Gamble account

    • Ad giant Omnicom (NYSE:OMC) has jumped 1.8% as it's taking over most of the media buying and planning for Procter & Gamble, taking a significant chunk of business from Publicis Groupe (OTCQX:PUBGY +0.3%).
    • Publicis' Starcom Mediavest Group handled most of P&G's North American media; Omnicom reportedly didn't have any of the consumer-products giant's business previously.
    • It's not entirely unexpected but still a blow to Publicis, which went into an unusually heavy review period this summer with the most to lose among its peers.
    • Billings up for review this year were more than the past three years combined; the P&G account has been one of the most heavily watched pitches, as the company is the world's biggest ad spender.
    • Previously: Publicis +2.3%, sets major restructuring into four hubs for 2016 (Dec. 03 2015)
    • Previously: Volatile summer for ad agencies with $26B under review (Jun. 12 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:07 PM
  • NFLX

    Netflix hints at interest in sports during conference presentation

    • Netflix (NFLX -2.4%) is lower after execs presented at the UBS Global Media and Communications Conference. Shares initially moved higher to set yet another all-time high before backtracking.
    • Chief Content Officer Ted Sarandos detailed the 31 original series and 10 feature films slated to be on the streaming menu next year. Comedy specials will also be a key feature in 2016.
    • The most interesting reveal was the hint from Sarandos that the company would consider an entry into sports through its own league.
    • The biggest negative from the presentation may have been the warning on the difficulty of striking global licensing deals with programmers.
    • UBS conference webcast
     
     
     
     
    | 11:56 AM | 20 Comments
  • ARWR

    Arrowhead's lead product candidate shows encouraging results in preclinical preclinical study; shares up 12%

    • Micro cap Arrowhead Research (ARWR +11.6%) moves up on modestly higher volume in response to its announcement of positive results for lead product candidate ARC-520, an RNAi-based therapeutic, in a study involving chronically hepatitis B-infected chimpanzees. Seven of nine (78%) showed signs of immune reactivation after receiving the combination of ARC-520 and nucleoside analogs, a necessary step for achieving a functional cure of chronic HBV.
    • Two mid-stage studies evaluating ARC-520 in HBV are ongoing. Chronic HBV infection afflicts as many as 400M people worldwide.
    • Previously: Arrowhead's hep B candidate ARC-520 knocks down circulating surface antigen as much as 99% after single dose in mid-stage study; shares up 35% premarket (Sept. 24)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:37 AM | 11 Comments
  • SXL

    Sunoco Logistics to sell units up to $1B

    • Sunoco Logistics (SXL -10.1%) plunges following late Friday's disclosure that it plans to sell up to $1B worth of common units.
    • SXL says it intends to use the proceeds for general partnership purposes, which may include repaying or refinancing all or a portion of its debt, and funding working capital, capital spending or acquisitions.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:31 AM | 3 Comments
  • KMI

    Kinder Morgan should cut dividend to $0.01, analyst says

    • Kinder Morgan (KMI -6.9%) plunges again following seven consecutive down days, this time after Jefferies analyst Christopher Sighinolfi writes that a dividend cut to $0.01/quarter through 2017 is the most prudent action to fund capex, preserve KMI's investment grade rating and protect the company from capital market risks.
    • Such a dividend reduction, combined with a reinstatement to $2 in 2018 with 5% annual growth through 2020, would enable KMI to fully fund its capex without any equity issuance and de-lever its balance sheet, repositioning KMI's financial and competitive posture for years to come, Sighinolfi says.
    • Separately, Morgan Stanley's private wealth team is removing its 2% position in KMI from its model portfolio, according to Notable Calls.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:17 AM | 64 Comments
  • MTEM

    Threshold's lead product candidate flunks two late-stage trials; shares plummet 83%

    • Nano cap Threshold Pharmaceuticals (THLD -82.7%) drops through the floor on a massive 23x surge in volume in response to its announcement that lead product candidate evofosfamide (formerly TH-302) failed two Phase 3 studies, MAESTRO and TH-CR-406/SARC021.
    • In MAESTRO, the regimen of evofosfamide plus gemcitabine failed to show a statistically valid improvement in overall survival (OS) compared to gemcitabine plus placebo in treatment-naive patients with advanced unresectable or metastatic pancreatic cancer (p=0.0589).
    • In TH-CR-406/SARC021, the regimen of evofosfamide and doxorubicin failed to show a statistically valid improvement in OS compared to doxorubicin alone in patients with locally advanced unresectable or metastatic soft tissue sarcoma (p value not disclosed).
    • Evofosfamide is an investigational hypoxia-activated prodrug which is activated under tumor hypoxic (low oxygen) conditions which typify many cancers. Low oxygen levels in solid tumors are due to insufficient blood supply as a result of abnormal vasculature.
    • Full results will be submitted for presentation at future scientific conferences and for publication.
    • Co-developer Merck KGaA (OTCPK:MKGAF)(OTCPK:MKGAY) has canceled its commercialization plans for the product.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:17 AM | 5 Comments
  • JBLU

    Airline stocks react to swing lower in oil

    • Airline stocks are rallying after crude oil prices swing lower and with several November traffic reports showing revenue passenger miles outpacing capacity gains.
    • JetBlue (JBLU +4.1%), Republic Airways (RJET +3.5%), Delta Air Lines (DAL +2.5%), and Hawaiian Holdings (HA +2.2%) are making the sharpest moves in morning trading.
    • Previously: Energy shares tank as U.S. crude oil slides 4% (Dec. 07 2015)
    • Related ETF: JETS.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:16 AM | 1 Comment
  • PBY-OLD

    52-week high for Pep Boys after Icahn action

    • Pep Boys (PBY-OLD +2.7%) confirms it received notice of the 12% position acquired in the company by Carl Icahn through his entities.

  • ABGOF

    Arizona solar plant secure despite parent Abengoa's turmoil, DoE says

    • Arizona's largest solar power plant - the Solana generating station near Gila Bend - will remain in operation despite its parent company's financial meltdown, according to a U.S. Department of Energy official.
    • Abengoa (ABGB -11.1%), the Spanish company that owns Solana, is on the verge of liquidating assets in preparation for possible bankruptcy, but the DoE says the U.S. is protected if ABGB goes into bankruptcy; Solana, which earns revenue by selling power to Arizona Public Service Co., was built with a $1.5B loan guarantee from the U.S. government to Abengoa Yield (ABY -2.9%) and Liberty, a company separate from the parent company; ABGB, however, is the largest investor in ABY.
    • ABGB also is the parent owner of Mohave solar plant in California, which also should not be affected either, the DoE says.
    • Separately, Bloomberg reports that ABGB will meet with its main creditor banks this week as it seeks to line up the funds it may need to avoid insolvency.

  • XOM

    Energy shares tank as U.S. crude oil slides 4%

    • The energy sector (-4.5%) paces the opening decline, as WTI crude oil prices -4% at $38.35/bbl following a 2.7% slide on Friday after OPEC's failure to agree on a production target to reduce the oil glut.
    • Investors are betting on oil prices staying lower for even longer after OPEC's non-decision, pushing U.S. crude futures for delivery nearly 10 years away below $60/bbl, Reuters reports.
    • But the oil glut is set to continue as much because of the U.S. as of OPEC, as U.S. shale drillers have only trimmed their pumping a little, and rising oil flows from the Gulf of Mexico are propping up U.S. production; the overall output of U.S. crude fell just 0.2% in September, the most recent monthly federal data available, and is down less than 3%, to 9.3M bbl/day, from the peak in April.
    • Goldman Sachs says it expects oil prices to remain "lower for longer," with a risk that prices could fall as low as $20/bbl.
    • In early trading: XOM -2.9%, CVX -4.1%, BP -3.2%, RDS.A -4.2%, COP -4.6%, MPC -3.2%, MRO -7.4%, PSX -2.8%, HES -4.9%, APC -6.1%, OXY -3.1%, EOG -5.8%, DVN -9.3%, PXD -7.2%, APA -3.9%, CHK -8%, CLR -9.1%.

  • AAUKF

    Anglo American plunges to record low

    • Anglo American (OTCQX:AAUKF, OTCPK:AAUKY) sinks to new all-time lows, falling to as low as £3.70 ($5.59) in London trading, the lowest since the company went public in 1999.
    • Anglo is among the most diversified miners, with EBIT spread among iron ore and manganese (27%), coal (14%), copper (9%), diamonds (31%) and platinum (14%) in H1 2015, but the miner is being penalized for its diversity, as nearly all commodities have amid softening demand by China.
    • "What you tend to find in most crises is that correlations [between commodities] move one way and everything craps out together," says Bernstein analyst Paul Gait, a former Anglo executive who still advises buying the company’s stock because of its large reserves of commodities such as copper.
    • Mining giants BHP Billiton (NYSE:BHP) and Rio Tinto (NYSE:RIO) are far more exposed to a single commodity - iron ore - and have performed far better than their more diversified competitors; the companies have been able to weather the sharp drop in iron ore prices because their mines run at far lower costs than competitors, including Anglo.
    • Earlier: Dow Jones: Anglo American to slash dividend, timing uncertain (Dec. 3)

  • AGIO

    ASH-tainted investors shun Agios Pharma despite positive early-state data; shares slump 13% in early trading

    • Agios Pharmaceuticals (AGIO -13.3%) heads south in early trading in apparent sympathy with bluebird bio (BLUE -29.4%) and Global Blood Therapeutics (GBT -18%). Over the weekend, the company presented Phase 1 data on AG-120 in advanced blood cancers at the American Society of Hematology annual meeting in Orlando, FL.
    • 87 patients with with IDH1 mutation-positive hematologic malignancies showed a favorable safety profile while 78 dose-escalation patients showed durable clinical activity. The overall response rate was 35% (n=27/78) and the complete response rate was 15% (n=12/78) in patients on therapy for a median of 2.9 months (range: 0.1 - 14.1 months). The median duration of response was 5.6 months (upper range: 12.5 months).
    • AG-120 is an inhibitor of the mutated form of the metabolic enzyme IDH1 (isocitrate dehydrogenase 1) which is present in a wide range of cancers.
    • Previously: Agios Pharma's AG-120 shows encouraging results in blood cancer (June 12)

  • BLCM

    Bellicum's lead product candidate shows positive results in early-stage study in children with genetic disorders; shares up 9% premarket

    • Thinly traded micro cap Bellicum Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:BLCM) is up 9% premarket on increased volume in response to its announcement of encouraging results from a Phase 1/2 clinical trial assessing lead product candidate BPX-501 in children with a range of genetic disorders, including severe combined immunodeficiency disease, beta thalassemia, Fanconi anemia and Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. The data were presented at the American Society of Hematology annual meeting in Orlando, FL.
    • Initial outcomes were reported from 39 pediatric patients from the trial site in Europe. Twenty had non-malignant genetic disorders and 19 had blood cancers, most with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. In the 37 patients with a minimum of 30 days' follow up, there was no transplant-related mortality (TRM), which compared favorably with the historical level of 9%. Non-malignant patients achieved a T cell count of 500 cells/ul in ~40 fewer days compared to historical controls and were discharged from the hospital 21 days sooner post transplant. No infusion-related adverse events were observed. There were seven instances of grade 1 or 2 graft-versus-host disease that were all resolved without requiring the activation of the CaspaCIDe safety switch with rimiducid.
    • BPX-501 is an adjunct T cell therapy administered after an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant, using genetically modified donor T cells incorporating the CaspaCIDe safety switch (designed to eliminate cells in the event of toxicity).
    • The company will host an investor/analyst luncheon today at 12:15 pm to discuss the results.

  • GBT

    Weighted down by bluebird bio, Global Blood Therapeutics slumps 17% premarket on GBT440 sickle cell data

    • Thinly traded relatively recent IPO Global Blood Therapeutics (NASDAQ:GBT) is off 17% premarket on increased volume in response to clinical trial results for lead product candidate GBT440 in sickle cell disease (SCD). The data were presented yesterday at the American Society of Hematology annual meeting in Orlando, FL.
    • In a Phase 1/2 study, called GBT440-001, two groups of SCD patients who were treated with either 500 mg/day or 700 mg/day of GBT440 for 28 days showed median reductions in sickle cell counts of 56% and 46%, respectively, compared to placebo's 14%. Encouraging results to be sure, but less than 100% (n=6/6) "significant reductions" that was disclosed in the company's IPO prospectus (page 2).
    • SCD patients receiving 500 mg or 700 mg GBT440 also showed median increases in hemoglobin concentration of 0.5 and 0.7 g/dL, respectively, versus 0.1 g/dL for placebo and median reductions in reticulocyte (immature red blood cells) counts of 31% and 37%, respectively, compared to a 7% increase for placebo.
    • GBT440 is an oral, once-daily SCD therapy that works by increasing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. Oxygenated hemoglobin does not polymerize which prevents the trademark sickling of red blood cells.
    • Management will review the GBT440 data today in a presentation at 12:30 pm ET.
    • Previously: Global Blood Therapeutics on deck for IPO (Aug. 7)

  • BLUE

    Disappointing results for bluebird bio's gene therapy in sickle cell disease and a subtype of beta thalassemia sink shares, down 32% premarket

    • Bluebird bio (NASDAQ:BLUE) slumps 32% premarket on increased volume in response to its presentation yesterday at the American Society of Hematology (ASH) annual meeting on its gene therapy platform for the treatment of sickle cell disease (SCD) and beta thalassemia.
    • Investors are disappointed that patients with severe SCD treated with the company's LentiGlobin BB305 (Study HGB-206) in a Phase 1 trial are not responding as quickly as expected. In two patients three months post infusion, the proportion of anti-sickling hemoglobin was only 17% and 16%, respectively. A level of 30% is needed to achieve a disease-modifying clinical effect.
    • In a study in beta thalassemia, (HGB-205), two subjects with the b0/bE genotype have remained transfusion independent for 23.4 months and 20.1 months, respectively, after a single infusion of LentiGlobin BB305 while one SCD patient showed a proportion of anti-sickling hemoglobin of 49%. Three patients with the b0/b0 subtype, however, failed to maintain transfusion independence (originally reported in November).
    • Lentiglobin BB305 is a gene therapy that inserts a functional human beta-globin gene into the patient's own hematopoietic stems cells in a process performed outside of the body. The modified cells are then infused into the patient.
    • Previously: Bluebird bio down 8% premarket on Q3 miss and disappointing Northstar data (Nov. 5)
    • Previously: Bluebird bio black and blue after report of gene therapy patient needing blood transfusions (Oct. 19)
